[This is a treatment for a screenplay.  The working title is "Vegetable Stand".] It started at the supermarket in the New England suburb of Stepford.  A housewife in the produce section was blasted with pulp when a rutabaga exploded. Over the next few weeks, rutabagas blew up in supermarkets around the country.  There were no significant injuries, but plenty of messes.  Tabloids were full of stories about celebrities who'd been rutabagaed. At first, the whole thing was considered a prank, and was attributed to bored teenagers.  After all, what could be more natural than kids wanting to blow up vegetables?  The only serious effort to stop the trend was a public service campaign called "This is Your Brain on Rutabagas."  Nobody understood it, but at least late night TV talk shows had an abundance of material. Then everything changed.  A TV station in Seattle received a letter from a group that called itself the "Rutabaga Liberation Army."  On the envelope were strange markings that forensic scientists thought might be some foreign language.  America was under attack.  The public was horrified; their own vegetables were being used against them. A professor of rutabaga science conjectured that terrorists might be growing vegetables next to abandoned Cold War weapons plants.  The Department of Homeland Security assured everyone that rutabagas were harmless.  But to make sure, they requested a twenty-million-dollar grant from Congress to randomly test rutabagas for radiation.  A spokesman from DHS told the public that if they didn't continue eating rutabagas, the terrorists had won. Half of Congress gathered for a media event on the steps of the Capitol, to gobble what the Capitol cafeteria called "Freedom Fruit."  Patriotism was a shopping bag full of rutabagas. But not everyone was satisfied with the official line.  The country was polarized.  Half the population believed that rutabagas were a terrorist vegetable and refused to eat them.  The other half insisted that eating rutabagas was one way ordinary patriotic Americans could stand up to terrorism. Soaring demand caused a rutabaga shortage.  Several members of the Organization of Rutabaga-Exporting Countries talked about using rutabagas as an economic weapon against the United States.  Overnight, public sentiment turned against rutabagas. That's when the violence against rutabaga farmers began.  A dazed man fell from a truck and was found in the street by a mob, lying in what appeared to be a pile of rutabagas.  He was almost lynched before the cryptic vegetables were identified as turnips.  Farms known to produce rutabagas suffered arson at twice the rate of farms producing only turnips. Security companies that examined the belongings of people entering public buildings began to screen for rutabagas.  The Transportation Security Administration prohibited rutabagas on airplanes.  A woman was caught trying to smuggle one onto a plane.  She had disassembled it, cooked it, and hidden the parts in a vegetable stew.  A team in hazmat suits carried her lunch onto the tarmac and blew it up.  The White House Press Secretary exhibited satellite photographs of secret trailers full of rutabagas in Iran. Congress voted to spend three hundred million dollars for research on alternative vegetables.  Within a week of the first public service announcements urging everyone to support the Parsnip Movement, six parsnips detonated in supermarkets.  The American people were stunned.  Global warming and gay marriage were forgotten. Nobody had ever been brought to justice for the rutabaga attacks, and the public was enraged.  Congress passed the Killer Rutabagas And Parsnips Act, which created a federal agency with a four-billion-dollar budget.  Using recent discoveries in quantum gravitational theory, new vegetable detectors were developed and installed in airports.  Expenses were much larger than expected; the budget had to be doubled.  Other law enforcement programs were looted to supply the funds.  In the six months after passage of the KRAP Act, there were ten thousand more robberies than in a similar period a year earlier. Over time, the panic faded.  People forgot that rutabagas existed -- which in America, they didn't.  The War Against Vegetables appeared to be won. And then a shopper was pushing a cart full of groceries to her car when they were destroyed by an incendiary banana in one of the bags.  Exploding vegetables were one thing, but bananas were fruit.  This changed everything.  Again. Next came the broccoli bombs.  Desperation reigned.  Prisons could barely be built fast enough to house the burgeoning population of vegetable abusers.  And vegetable abuse was construed ever more broadly.  Anyone who had the nerve to point out that "vegetable abuse" was meaningless double-talk was suspected of being a vegetable sympathizer, and was spirited away to a secret prison. Nobody knew what might happen next.  People started eating snack cakes instead of fruits and vegetables.  To promote the illusion of a healthy diet, scientists at the Junk Food Institute developed a snack cake with a peel.  The cake failed commercially because of persistent rumors that it was made from petroleum byproducts.  Which it was.  With the rapid diet changes, America was overwhelmed by simultaneous obesity and malnutrition. American agriculture, its reputation demolished, could not compete in the world market.  The balance of payments deteriorated, petroleum became scarce, prices rose and buying power plummeted.   The American economy reeled.  Half the world suffered through a profound depression, and the global balance of power shuddered. And then the FBI announced they had discovered the perpetrators.  A group of teenagers around the country had carried out the vegetable attacks, using the Internet for coordination.  (The banana bombs had been copycat crimes by jealous adults.)  But the kids all insisted that some powerful and enigmatic entity was behind the attacks.  Finally, several informants independently named the Junk Food Institute.  The FBI was getting ready to raid the headquarters of the JFI when the investigation was abruptly abandoned, three days after the President's surprising re-election. Too much about the attacks was never explained. From the winning entry: "No warning is given to the dams downriver, other than the generation at G.C. is now offline."  Not at all likely.  Ask the Bonneville Power Administration and the Corps of Engineers and Bureau of Reclamation, who actually run most of the dams on the Columbia mainstem, about the SCADA systems for integrating the grid and about the extensive flow monitoring on the river.  There are security provisions which aren't and should not be public, but in general, our regional grid is perhaps the best engineered in the world, and even a massive failure at Grand Coulee would be isolated and "islanded" within less than a second.  There are always enough "spinning reserves" on the system to provide reliability throughout the grid.  This does not rule out an occasional cascading failure as occurred in 1995 when a tree limb shorted out a transmission line in central Oregon and did shut down much of the west coast for a brief period.  System outages occur daily -- see for example the logs at http://www.transmission.bpa.gov/orgs/opi/outages/DIR/TODAY.HTM.  Downstream dams have enough storage capacity to hold even a flood surge from Grand Coulee.  Of course, any major infrastructure like the Northwest power system is a potential target, but frankly I worry a lot more about ammonia on railcars and things like that which are ubiquitous and not at all well monitored.  The plot for your winner is a pageturner, I guess, but any system planner or engineer knows it's only good enough for a bad TV movie.

OK this is pure genius.  You'll need about a thousand people in on this.  You are going to need a hell of a collection of old cars.  The reason is you need to have cars that have engines that predate electronic ignition.  What you do with these cars is remove the condenser from the ignition system, and drive them around a major metropolitan area, say Manhattan. These older ignition systems use what are called breaker points.  Without the condenser to muffle the spark arcing across the points the ignition system the breaker points will act like a spark gap transmitter.  Spark gap transmitters aren't tuned to any particular frequency, so the end result is a broad range of radio interference. Multiplied by several thousand cars you have enough energy to wipe out most digital communication in a small area, or you can drive them around and wreak havoc with cell phones, wi-fi even civilian and police band radios.
